awd_titl_txt: Partial Differential Equation Constrained Optimization:  Algorithms, Numerics, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The state of the art in modeling of the physical processes in science and engineering confronts us with solving increasingly complex optimization problems in the presence of constraints.  Think of designing the wing of an aircraft where it is essential that it can withstand a tremendous amount of pressure. This is just one of the example of an optimization problem with constrains. Such problems are inherently nonlinear due to constraints. This makes the development and analysis of algorithms and numerical techniques for the solution of these problems extremely challenging but rewarding. This project will create new optimization algorithms that allows us to incorporate constraints in a systematic and robust fashion. The targeted applications range from next generation micro- and nano-scale lab-on-chip devices to novel material and structural designs. Open source software will be created so that the research can be easily used by scientists working in other research areas.
 
The applications under consideration can be modeled using partial differential equations (PDEs). These PDEs are  nonlocal (fractional); nonsmooth (contact problems); geometric, nonlinear, multiscale with an unknown domain, i.e. free boundary problems (FBPs). This project focuses on optimization problems with such PDE constraints - the so-called PDE constrained optimization problems. It aims to create new optimization schemes that will enable the solution of currently intractable optimization problems with nonsmooth features, including: optimization problems with nonlinear inequality constraints, contact problems, and risk-averse PDE constrained optimization. The resulting optimization algorithms will provide new insights into nonconvex nonsmooth problems. Optimization problems with surface tension is a new research field with great potential to enhance our understanding at the micro and nano-scales where surface effects dominate bulk effects. This will impact the design of next generation lab-on-chip, forensics and liquid lenses in astronomical telescopes. Open source software will be developed, which will not only benefit scientists in optimization, FBPs, and nonlocal problems but also scientists in nonlinear PDEs and data driven optimization problems. The results will be disseminated via two special topics courses on (i) PDE constrained optimization under uncertainty; (ii) Deep learning and PDE constrained optimization. One female student will get her PhD.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The state of the art in modeling of the physical processes in science and engineering confronts us with solving increasingly complex optimization problems in the presence of constraints. These constraints are typically given by partial differential equations (PDEs). The goal of this project has been to study optimization problems with PDEs as constraints and to create novel optimization algorithms to handle such problems. We call such problems as PDE constrained optimization (PDECO) problems. In particular, within the project, we have worked on the following set of problems: 1) PDECO or optimal control problems and generic optimization algorithms in infinite dimensions. 2) Analysis and numerical methods for PDECO with nonlinear and nonsmooth PDEs as constraints. 3) Risk-averse optimal design of engineered systems based on fractional (nonlocal) PDEs. 4) Novel optimal control concepts and fractional (nonlocal) PDEs. 5) Reduced order methods for parametrized systems. 6) Training of postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students. 7) Creation of special topics courses: a) Deep learning and PDE constrained optimization; b) Risk averse PDE constrained optimization. 

The project conducted simulations of air flows in an effort to understand, minimize and possibly suppress the spread of pathogens such as Covid-19. Various settings were considered, including hospital rooms, TSA queues, subways, classrooms, and courtrooms. For the courtrooms, collaborations took place with the chief judges of MD, NYSD, and NYED. In addition to modeling and testing air flow, the following optimization problem was addressed: given an arbitrary number of contamination scenarios, what is the minimum number of sensors needed for detection, and where should they be placed? The effort on metro trains, airplanes and usage of masks, was published in the NY Times and Computational Mechanics and Archives of Computational Methods in Engineering.

The project has created novel optimization algorithms that can withstand a high level of error in the system at each iteration which is necessary for large systems. It has developed analytical and numerical tools to solve optimization problems with free boundary problems (FBPs) as constraints. Such problems require nonstandard tools for their analysis. The project has created risk-averse optimization framework for optimization problems constrained by nonlocal / fractional PDEs. The project has introduced novel concepts of optimal control, for instance, exterior control. It has led to new models in imaging science, in particular bilevel optimization problems, where machine learning has played a central role. New models based on nonlocal operators have been introduced in geophysics which have been validated by numerical experiments.

The novel optimization algorithms created under the project are providing new insights into nonconvex nonsmooth problems. This is especially true for bilevel optimization problems. The study undertaken for FBPs is providing new insights at the micro and nano-scales where surface effects dominate bulk effects. This will impact the design of next generation lab-on-chip, forensics etc. The work on nonlocal problems in geophysics has led to a lot of excitement in the geophysics community. Several of the algorithms created are available under open-source codes. 

During the proposal period, the PI has organized 9 minisymposia at national and international meetings. In addition, the PI has organized 8 major conferences and summer schools. He also taught at multiple summer schools. The PI and his graduate students gave over 100 talks at the national and international conferences, including multiple keynote and plenary talks. Moreover, the PI has created 2 special topics courses at the graduate level. The project has resulted in 25 peer reviewed publications and in addition 1 book. The PI has supervised 2 undergraduate students, 3 MS students, 7 PhD students (2 students completed their PhDs) and 2 postdocs.
